column10: COMMENTS (either add comments here or using the comment function in a given cell. Do not write in the cell itself!)
column13: Number of coauthors from non-academic institutions
column14: Number of coauthors from governmental organizations (USGS, etc)
column15: Forecast spatial scale (point, multipoint, regional, national, global)
column16: If spatial scale is "point" or "multipoint": geographic coordinates from google maps (see notes)
column17: Forecast ecosystem: forest, grassland, freshwater, marine, desert, tundra, atmosphere, agricultural, urban, global, other
column18: Forecast class: biogeochemical or organismal (population or community)
column19: How many forecast variables are discussed in the paper
column24: If specified: more detailed description of model (e.g., Bayesian hierarchical, machine learning, named model (e.g., PROTECH), etc)
column25: Model covariate class(es) used in this study: meteorological, physical, chemical, or biological
column26: Does the paper explicitly identify that random effects were included? (y/n)
column27: Does the paper explicitly talk about latent variables, using this terminology? (y/n)
column32: Are multiple modeling approaches compared (NOT including null models)? (y/n)
column36: What type of null model (e.g. climatology, persistence)
column38: Time step of forecast output (in days)
column39: How often are new forecasts produced (in days)
column41: Model training period mentioned in paper? (y/n)
column43: Iterative forecast (i.e., data updating forecasts iteratively)? (y/n)
column44: What technique of data assimilation? (e.g., KF, enKF, refit, update IC, etc)
column45: Latency of observation data for assimilation (response variable). If not provided, mark "unspecified." Convert units to days
column47: If uncertainty is propagated: Is uncertainty propagation analytic or ensemble-based?
column48: What sources of uncertainty were incorporated?
column56: If at least two categories of uncertainty were partitioned, what was the dominant source of uncertainty?
column57: If the dominant source varies by forecast horizon, season, etc. please describe here
column60: Paper states that forecast was evaluated (y/n)
column61: Forecast evaluation results reported in paper (y/n)
column62: List all skill metrics used (e.g. R2, RMSE, bias, MAE)
column63: Is forecast performance assessed at multiple forecast horizons (results must be reported in paper/supplimental info)? (y/n)
column64: How many forecasting cycles are evaluated/assessed, with the results reported in the paper? (PLEASE READ NOTES HERE)
column65: How many total forecasting cycles are included for that variable in this paper (both those that are evaluated and those that are not)
column66: Maximum forecast horizon such that the forecast is better than the null model (out of any models used). Provide answer in days
column68: Maximum driver latency (latency of the driver with the longest latency). If not specified write "UNK". Provide answer in days
column69: Minimum driver latency (latency of the driver with the shortest latency). If not specified write "UNK". Provide answer in days
column70: Temporal coverage of data used to create this forecasting paper (in days; your best guess is fine here)
column71: Is new data (driver and/or observations) available to the model in real time (<24 hours from collection) without any manual effort when the system is working as intended? (y/n)
column73: Repository in which forecasts are archived
column74: Paper specifies that driver data are publicly available to reproduce the forecasts (according to the paper)
column77: Partnership w/ stakeholder in forecast development mentioned in paper (y/n)
column78: Forecast being used by stakeholder according to paper (y/n)
column79: Type of end user (general public vs institution)

column4: Trevor Page; Paul J.Smith; Keith J.Beven; Ian D.Jones; J. Alex Elliott; Stephen C.Maberly; Eleanor B.Mackay; Mitzi De Ville; Heidrun Feuchtmayr

column3: Developing an automated iterative near-term forecasting system for an ecological study
column4: White, EP; Yenni, GM; Taylor, SD; Christensen, EM; Bledsoe, EK; Simonis, JL; Ernest, SKM

column3: Fuzzy modeling of cyanobacterial surface waterblooms: Validation with NOAA-AVHRR satellite images
column4: Ibelings, BW; Vonk, M; Los, HFJ; van der Molen, DT; Mooij, WM
column10: It sets the stage for a forecast but does not explicitly perform forecasting.  It uses observed meterology in the main analysis.  It does do a simple senstivity study to evaluate the how the predictions of the model are influenced by uncertainity in wind predictions.  I would call this a pre-forecast.

column3: Complexity is costly: a meta-analysis of parametric and non-parametric methods for short-term population forecasting
column4: Ward, EJ; Holmes, EE; Thorson, JT; Collen, B
column9: is a forecast! but is a meta-analysis of multiple forecast studies, addressing model complexity and predictability. could be used to assess multiple studies
column10: This is meta-analysis of time-series modeling - they "forecast" the last 5 time steps of each data stream but this is in the past.  Plus they "forecast" so many different time series it is hard to figure out how to include in the matrix.  Very hard to figure out the forecast horizon and time-step.  Definitely a forecasting paper but almost too much forecasting.
column24: ARIMA model, regression models, non-parameteric models

column3: Towards a predictive model of species interaction beta diversity
column9: yes; annual forecast of species interactions
column10: This is an idea and synthesis paper that presents modeling framework.  The is a box that presents a 1-year protype that isn't really evaluated.  It is limited in its description.  I am leaning to excluding

column3: Population dynamics and control of invasive Spartina alterniflora: inference and forecasting under uncertainty
column4: Buhle, ER; Feist, BE; Hilborn, R
column8: the only forecasting done (based on abstract) is on scenarios which are not testable
column9: yes; used hindcasted drivers and scenarios of Spartina mgmt
column10: This is barely a forecast thought they give results for a year after the paper was published.

column3: Harvest models of small populations of a large carnivore using Bayesian forecasting
column4: Andren, H; Hobbs, NT; Aronsson, M; Broseth, H; Chapron, G; Linnell, JDC; Odden, J; Persson, J; Nilsen, EB

column3: Assimilating remote sensing data into a crop model to improve predictive performance for spatial applications
column10: No forecasting drivers and only a prediction after data assimilation.  Forecasting is only mention as a possible application

column3: The Montana deer and Elk hunting population: The importance of cohort group, license price, and population demographics on hunter retention, recruitment, and population change
column4: Schorr, RA; Lukacs, PM; Gude, JA
column9: I think this counts because the primary drivers are ecological and humans are treated as an organism
column10: Forecasting human variable.  There aren't ecological drivers.  It uses an ecological analysis tool (mark-recapture)

column3: Assessing the multi-pathway threat from an invasive agricultural pest: Tuta absoluta in Asia
column4: McNitt, J; Chungbaek, YY; Mortveit, H; Marathe, M; Campos, MR; Desneux, N; Brevault, T; Muniappan, R; Adiga, A
column9: modeling study which produces forecasts of potential spatial and temporal distributions based on multiple scenarios, projections are never validated
column10: This is an agent based model that has a stochastic component.  But doesn't use the concept of parameter uncertainity, process uncertainty, etc.

column3: The performance of the model AMBAV for evapotranspiration and soil moisture on Muncheberg data
column10: This paper is just a model run using observed drivers.  It mentions forecasts in the introduction but does not represent any results that resemble a forecast (i.e., no forecast horizon, etc)
